Headline: Chief Strategy Officer & Head, Investor Relations | ISB | DCE
Comment:
In a high TAM, hyper competitive market, the backend is the real deep competitive advantage. In such a market none of the players necessarily have "demand competitive advantage" as products are easily copied, brand salience is patchy and brand loyalty is non existent. 
Strong backend also gives an opportunity to build the  "economy of scale" competitive advantage by keeping the cost fixed and make use of a larger scale by scoring over competition due to the former.

Headline: Building Zewa | Creating sustainable aqua feeds | Unimelb Alumni | Temasek NextGen leader
Comment:
Balancing demand and supply is always a chicken and egg problem.

Rishabh Mariwala You are right on the capacity growing ahead of marketing, but it's all about the balance. Excess capacity also eats margins from lower production efficiency, overstocking, goods lost from damage and expiry,  and capital costs. Whereas slightly slower supply, though at the risk of some customer complaints and loss, can create demand if the product is unique and push the margins. Many established companies create artificial supply scarcity purely to increase margins and demand.
processed_comment: balancing demand and supply is always a chicken and egg problem rishabh mariwala you are right on the capacity growing ahead of marketing but its all about the balance excess capacity also eats margins from lower production efficiency overstocking goods lost from damage and expiry and capital costs whereas slightly slower supply though at the risk of some customer complaints and loss can create demand if the product is unique and push the margins many established companies create artificial supply scarcity purely to increase margins and demand

Comment:
So true. Weâ€™ve figured this piece outâ€”right from raw material sourcing to packaging proximity.
We simplify SKUs by limiting components (1â€“2 per SKU), which makes procurement and production far more scalable.

Weâ€™ve structured our credit cycles to allow repayment flexibility, while staying disciplined enough not to overextend.
We buy what we need, not what we hope weâ€™ll need.
And our marketplace logisticsâ€”both shipping and inwardingâ€”are fully dialed in.

Weâ€™re bootstrapped, growing YoY, and being frugal has only strengthened our fundamentals.

Interestingly, when we were previously at 50L MRR, we werenâ€™t as sustainable.
That scale exposed the cracksâ€”so we went back to the drawing board and rebuilt a system which can support us as we scale.
